lead_paragraph: AMES--Steven. Beloved husband and father, passed away on March 12, 2016. Steven was a committed patron of the arts, philanthropist and collector of PostWar and Contemporary Art. He had served as a trustee of numerous non-profit organizations, many of which have been involved in the arts. He was on the Board of the Whitney Museum of American Art and had chaired its Photography, Works-On-Paper and Collection Committees. Steven also served on the Executive Committee of the Board of the American Friends of the Israel Museum. He served on the Investment Committees of the Whitney Museum and AFIM, as well as having chaired AFIM's Contemporary Arts Acquisition Committee. In addition, he served for eight years on the investment Committee of the Annenberg Foundation. Steven has served as a Trustee of Aperture, Independent Curators, Inc. and United Cerebral Palsy. He was Chairman Emeritus of the Advisory Council of the Johnson Museum at Cornell University, where he endowed the position of Curator of Education. He and his wife Ann are former members of the Metropolitan's Chairman's Council and are long-standing members of the Collectors Committee of the National Gallery. Steven served on the Board of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center and has endowed various programs and professorships. He was Trustee and Director of the Harriett Ames Charitable Trust. For many years, he was a partner of Oppenheimer & Co. and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and was an active private investor. Steven held a BA '63 from Cornell, a JD '67 from Columbia Law School, and a Masters of Art History '95 from Columbia University. He is survived by his devoted wife Ann, his children, David and Marja Ames, Adam Ames and Elissa Levy, and David and Linna Sica along with his three grandchildren Max, Stella and Olivia. A service for family and friends will be held on Friday, March 18th at 11:30am at Campbell's Funeral Chapel. The family will also receive close friends between 5-9pm at the Carlyle Hotel in celebration of Steven's extraordinary life. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia Fighters/New York Presbyterian Hospital would be appreciated. 1/3
